Fields.DialogueText: Enjoying our brief stop here in London, Bulldog?
Bulldog? I asked you a question.
Oh? Sorry, I was miles away.
I noticed that happens sometimes when you're enjoying a pipe.
Apologies, Captain. I suppose our little stop in London is... a taste of home. I'm still chewing.

Fields.MenuText: A rare comfort in wartime. Try to enjoy it.
A distraction from our duties.
I'd rather be at sea.

Fields.DialogueText: I'll try not to enjoy it too much. No promises, mind.
If you can look home in the face until she blinks, you're a better soldier than I'll ever be.
That's our proper place. Well, my proper place. And yet...
We're heading out again soon, Bulldog, so make sure we're ready to go.
In the thick of it again. Time we earned last night's pints.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Everything's signed, sealed, and packed in its proper place.
Requisition forms?
Pre-filled with room for additions.
All your machinery in working order?
Guns and kettles polished and loaded.
All four boilers, too?
I've three and you know it.
Heh. Nothing gets past you, does it?
... Almost nothing.
Damned Morganas, trying to put holes in us.
Oi! Gimme that crowbar.
She's all yours. We'll get that Morgana shell out one way or another.
All righty. Stand aside while I get my back into it.
Unghhh!
Damage control teams are almost done with their repairs, Captain.
I can hear them all the way up here in the bridge.
That's them. Feels like they've almost got that Morgana round dislodged. Just a few more minutes and I'll be in top form again.
You can feel them prying it out?
Ngh...!
Yep. Right bastard of a place to get something lodged. But better a dud than the other sort.

Fields.MenuText: That must be painful.
I guess getting shot doesn't hurt as much for a Belle.
I wonder what else you can feel.

Fields.DialogueText: There's only so much edge this pipe can take off.
We can bounce back stronger. Doesn't mean it doesn't hurt like bloody hell. My sisters could tell you some grim stories.
That's for me to know, Captain, and for you to ideally never find out.
*CLANK*
It came out!
Of course it did. This is HMS Bulldog!
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Mmf. Just in time. My shoulder was getting stiff.
You'll have to tell me more about what that's like.
A Belle never forgets. My sisters Beagle and Basilisk collided once... they still don't speak except on holiday.
You called, Captain?
A while ago. We need to review our charts and assess the reports from HQ. That business in the Irish Sea is just the tip of the iceberg.
Didn't mean to keep you waiting. Well, not for any longer than would have been safe.
So sorry to have interrupted you while you were enjoying a pipe.
I've had some practice walking and smoking, I'll have you know.
Truth is, I was taking a minute to look at the faces on the shore.

Fields.MenuText: You're going to miss them?
Don't get too sentimental.
Looking for somebody in particular?

Fields.DialogueText: In a sense. I wish I could really nail down the words for it.
I'm the ghost of patriotism past, present, and yet to come. Sentiment comes with the territory.
Nothing like that, Captain. My first loves are Neptune and Britannia, in whichever order you please.
What, then?
Just checking their eyes, to make sure England still has some life in her.
And maybe a few stiff upper lips?
Hmm. I'd like to believe that. Reynolds certainly didn't.
You're still thinking about his mutiny?
It barely deserved the name. At the risk of sounding vain, he couldn't see his goal through his own infatuation.
What could his goal have been? I mean, how would he even have crewed you? You'd need a complement of-
@BATTLE
A hundred and forty-two. I've counted.
There's no way he could have gotten that many on board.
Whether or not he did, what matters is that he thought he could. Him, and everyone else driving their ship.
Which the Morganas conveniently destroyed.
Hmph. Symptoms sorting symptoms.
*ALARM*
What's on your mind?
I'll let you know when I've figured the proper words for it. We've fires to start.
What's this paperwork? A requisition form for more paint?
Red, white, and blue, Captain.
Painting yourself to match the sweater?
Not nearly so on the nose, though certainly in the neighbourhood of a cheekbone. I thought we'd keep a kill tally.
In patriotic colours.
Gives the struggle all the more meaning, doesn't it?

Fields.MenuText: Not all the crew are British.
That doesn't seem like enough paint for all of the kills we'll get.
That seems cocky.

Fields.DialogueText: Britishness isn't innate. Myself excluded.
That's the attitude a crew need to hear.
Only if we lose, and I'm not in the habit.
You remember when we left Britain, don't you? That fire I was looking for in the eyes of her people?
So we keep it burning out here at sea.
That's what I'm getting at. This is just kindling, of course. I'll find some real firewood down the line.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Jury's still out, Captain. I'll let the crew decide. For now, it's time we earned another stripe.
I didn't see it in Reynolds. Nor, I expect, would I have seen it in his friends.
Your hull, your rules. Are we starting with a clean slate or grandfathering in your old kills?
I can't stay here. I have a family!
I've eight sisters myself. We're jolly well aware of what we were signed up for.
If I get killed at sea...
You and everyone else with the privilege of fighting out here and not on the coasts. Make it count.
What's going on here?
Oh!
Frank exchange of views.
By your leave, Captain.
Orders of the day, then?

Fields.MenuText: That officer seemed scared.
That officer should go home and take care of his family.
Get that coward off my ship.

Fields.DialogueText: He's just anxious about combat. He'll be fine when his nerves settle.
The best way to protect his family is to protect ours.
Let me handle that one. He'll be right as rain when the time comes.
Bloody inconvenience, though.
If we send him home, it only scares the others worse, right?
Catching disease, it is. The crew are always watching.
Maybe you can let him paint the next kill tally.
*ALARM*
And on a more personal level, shipping that lovestruck spy back to Scotland Yard was the emotional equivalent of prising out that shell. I'll have no duds on board.
Or in the chamber. Let's get moving.
@BATTLE
Now there's a fine idea. He ought to be part of the solution.
You think he's a problem?
Symptoms, Captain. It's not his fault. He needs to feel he's part of something bigger. Reynolds certainly didn't.
Spot of fog rolling in.
Hm. The Morganas are going to use that.
No reason to let them monopolise it. What's good for the ugly duckling is good for the swan.
I know that's not how that phrase goes.
Bit optimistic besides if we're taking the fable literally. A Morgana's a Morgana, no matter how she evolves.
It does get awfully quiet when we're about to start a fight, even without the fog muffling things.

Fields.MenuText: Burn it off?
What's that song you like?
Play some music over the loudspeaker?

Fields.DialogueText: If you can find something we wouldn't mind burning, be my guest.
Precisely the direction my heart was drifting in.
Close, Captain, but you could be closer.
A little Heart of Oak always perks me up when things turn ominous. But I think I need a more central location to sing from. Up on the mast it is, then.
Whoa!
Come, cheer up, my lads, 'tis to glory we steer, to add something new to this wonderful-
Gah!
Easily solved, Captain.
Bulldog! Are you all right?
Like a half-eaten meat pie, Captain. Seems the Morganas tossed us a coin for our song.
Is that a shell!?
You're lucky I'm as good at rugby as at dominoes, Captain. War's a contact sport too, after all.
*ALARM*
Right! I think the crew heard. Harmonize with me, would you kindly?
@BATTLE
Right, lads and lasses, up you get!
Think that coat will last the patrol?
We've got plenty of paint if it doesn't. The crew were getting downright narky for this last tally.
I've been sensing an extra spring in their step. That's your influence, I take it.
Well, I can't take all the credit. If I give the crew something to believe in, it's because they're on top of their jobs.

Fields.MenuText: You're a hero, Bulldog. Don't deny it.
There's more to war than celebrating our kills.
We've got some of the best in the business.

Fields.DialogueText: I'll let our sailors be the judge of that. They're the ones who can go ashore with the stories.
They wouldn't be so keen to do it if they hadn't earned them.
Anyone can get that way with the right inspiration, I reckon.
We know how much damage we've done. What about the damage we've taken?
Written down in exquisite detail. I can practically feel every scorch and breach as I write them.
It makes me a unique writer. I'll let you be the judge of my prose. Besides, it's easier to write about something if you've experienced it.
You remember how my shoulder went all stiff when the crew were doing that Morgana shell. I wonder if I might not work that into the damage reports for the crew to read.
It'd certainly make them more relatable.
Got it in one. I prefer to let my work speak for itself, but a little familiarity might really drive the point home.
That makes you a good writer.
Hmm... hang on a tick.
Something on your mind?
*ALARM*
A shell to the boiler is one thing, but a punch to the gut is another.
Not when I'm through writing it up. Let's try not to have to, shall we?
@BATTLE
HQ's latest reports are in. Looks like our push into the Atlantic could go either way.
Listening to me, Bulldog?
Dodgy push into the Atlantic, right. Vigilance first, Captain.

Fields.MenuText: I wish you'd pay closer attention.
You're probably way ahead of me.
Something wrong?

Fields.DialogueText: Always, Captain. I can never focus on just one thing.
In certain arenas, but you've got me in others. A good command is an exchange.
Not wrong, Captain; I haven't blown anything up. Just... interesting.
Rest assured, Captain: whenever you call for fire, you will hear my guns.
I'm glad to hear it. You're not normally one of the more public Belles.
@BATTLE
Not to hear the newspapers tell it. A job's a job whether the Times fawn over it or not, and I'd prefer it simply be done.
But it's been educational to mingle between jobs. I'd say I've been getting on famously with that one officer you saw me bullying.
Having said that. I've been spending more time with the crew lately.
That's a strong word.
Only kind worth the breath, if I'm honest.
I think I understood him a little better once I asked him about the family... situation. There's a difference between the family you're born into and the family you fall into.
Which is the crew?
One that you build. One that we build. And the more they have a hand in building it, the less likely we are to see another Reynolds.
Nobody's as crazy as he is.
Nobody starts that way. But you see strange things from people left well enough alone. Easier to catch a shell before it strikes my shoulder, no?
*ALARM*
Fancy catching a few more?
I might hand one off to you if I do. It'd make a hell of a conversation piece.
Morganas in range, Captain.
Punish that left flank.
Shots away!
Direct hits. Nice work, Bulldog!
I'm focusing on the engines right now, Captain. Those shots were all the gunnery crew.

Fields.MenuText: I never would have guessed.
I'll have to single them out for commendation.
I didn't give the order to fire.

Fields.DialogueText: They've better eyes than you give them credit for, Captain. And they're improving.
On it! I've gallantly set aside some of my own tobacco ration for them to enjoy.
I did, Captain, precisely when the opportunity came round. They just had to learn what to look for.
I've a philosophy, Captain.
For war, or life in general?
I can understand how that works on the battlefield.
Both, come to think of it. The way you succeed is through the proper application of overwhelming force.
It has its applications elsewhere as well.
Reynolds crumpled after a kick to the jaw.
I'm not just talking about violence, Captain, fun as that is. A little incentive goes a long way. I've promised a reward to whoever happens to score the killing blow.
And if that person is you?
Why, you get it, of course.
And what's the reward?
Haven't decided. Cooperation may keep the kettle on, but competition gets the fire started. And speaking of starting fires...
@BATTLE
... And that was the last time any blighters from the Continent ever got one over on England. That hasn't changed in nine hundred years, nor will it ever. Any questions?
None!
One, two, three...
Bulldog?
Dismissed. Captain, you're just in time for the end of the impromptu history lecture.

Fields.MenuText: I didn't figure you for the lecturing type.
I wasn't invited?
When's the next one?

Fields.DialogueText: Neither did I, to tell you the truth. But the crew kept pestering me for it, and I figured it was easier than throwing them overboard. Less paperwork.
That'd make it a promptu one, wouldn't it? I didn't ask the crew to ask me for story time.
Whenever the crew grind my patience back down, I expect. I don't make a habit of this.
They seemed pretty fired up.
Didn't they say that about Rome?
They did indeed, but Britain did it better. You may quote me on that if any of the Italian girls happen to come skulking about.
It's not every day that the embodiment of a country tells you about its history. I'm curious about your perspective myself.
It's... complex, Captain.
Of course. I've got time.
*ALARM*
Another day, Captain. I'm sensing it's time to speak loudly again.
I'll hold you to it. Let's get to work!
@BATTLE
Now, now, don't get ahead of me. Heart of oak are our ships, jolly tars are our men, we always are ready: Steady, boys, steady!
Hard not to be once you've heard a little about our history. The Empire wasn't built in a day, you know.
I'm proud of my country, but words are words. Shells speak louder.
You're a damn good speaker off the cuff, you know. I've read that speech from the Aden incident. Everyone has.
All right to adjust course, Bulldog?
... Yeah ...
Didn't catch that. Are we-
Sorry, Captain. Vocal rest. I'm not used to speaking at length like I did... or singing right after.

Fields.MenuText: You can tell me if you're under the weather.
Anything I can do to help?
How long do you think you need?

Fields.DialogueText: If I ever am, Captain, it's time to start throwing people overboard, because something's gone funny.
A little honey in my tea and I'll be right. Ask anyone who's been in a chorus. There ought to be one or two aboard.
Another day should do it. I'll make do appearing at shoulders and speaking softly. It worked for Exeter that one time.
Got any other songs in your repertoire? Maybe "God Save the King" would be easier on your voice.
Probably, but I might capsize out of boredom before I finished the first verse.
Really? But you're so...
British, yes, I think we'd both gotten that far. And for me it's like singing about the roof of your house. It sits up top, but you come to visit for what's underneath.
Don't let the King hear you say that.
Of course not, Captain. The tabloids would feast on that for months.
*ALARM*
Let's make sure you don't get feasted on.
It's you I'm worried about, Captain. Even ship spirits prefer meat to steel.
@BATTLE
That one time?
When she awoke. It's her story to tell, and she tells it better.
I'll live. Sorry I'm late. The ship's doctor paid me a visit.
Everything shipshape?
It's not me. One of the crew is complaining about a bad back.
Oh, thank God. I thought it was something serious.

Fields.MenuText: A bad back can be serious. We might have to drop them off in port.
I hope the crew aren't malingering to avoid combat.
It's the doctor's job to worry about things like that.

Fields.DialogueText: Such pessimism. I've a better idea. Let me talk to them.
That cures even easier than a bad back, and in more or less the same way.
I'll solve it. Leave the worrying to the professionals.
Don't give it another thought, Captain. I'm on the case.
Bulldog, wait!
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Just what is her game? Well, can't care about that now...
I don't think we can just-
Proper application of overwhelming force, Captain. I'll pop down to the doctor and see who's crooked.
What do you know about fixing bad backs?
Ah, Captain, poor timing. I had to finish this pot of tea.
You called for me, Captain?
Come in and close the door.
Blimey, this is getting interesting.
I heard a report about Midshipman Winthrop, the one with the bad back.
Think nothing of it. Problem solved.
About that...
The ship's doctor tells me you bent Winthrop over the lifelines and wrenched her back until she said it didn't hurt anymore.
That's right. Anything else to fix before we're ready for the front lines again?

Fields.MenuText: You aren't a doctor, Bulldog.
Don't mistreat the crew.
Thanks for clearing that up.

Fields.DialogueText: I don't have to be a fox to know how to catch a rabbit.
I'd never do that. Winthrop gave me the all clear. Seemed quite happy at the prospect.
It's what I'm here for. Now the doctor can attend to more serious problems.
Hmm. I'll talk to Winthrop next time I see her.
Do, Captain. It's a charming story, and she paints a rare picture with her words.
Well, I suppose that's... do you hear that?
"God Save the Bits?"
I never could decipher that kind of language.
They're referring to me, Captain. With a bit of rhyming slang thrown in.
Singing. Almost sounds like... oh, Lord love a duck.
You don't want to. It's bloody juvenile.
I wouldn't mind a song about me now and again.
I admit it's endearing. Whatever gets them through the day. But the minute they start praying to me is the minute I crack some heads to go with the spines.
You sure? I hear the Archbishop of Canterbury was throwing around words like "angel" and "canonization."
I'll leave that for humans who rise to the occasion. If you could build your own saints, you wouldn't need us, would you?
Probably. But we're happy to have you.
Happy to be here. Your tobacco's downright spiffing.
*ALARM*
Hmm. Might ask these Morganas for a light.
@BATTLE
Repairs are nearly complete, Bulldog.
Excuse me?
I said what I said.

Fields.MenuText: I have the report straight from the gunnery crew.
What's going on?
Is it going to keep us out of the fight?

Fields.DialogueText: Then we've identified the source of the problem, haven't we?
My left hand. It's feeling downright arthritic.
I'd know if it were life-threatening. It shouldn't be.
I know my Shakespeare, Captain, and your Falstaff needs work.
How's your Prince Hal?
Straining upon the start. See to the rest of me. I'll handle my AA.
If you're sure.
It takes more than a dodgy paw to take a bulldog off the field.
@BATTLE
No, they're not.
*ALARM*
Isn't it obvious, Captain? We fight.
Not if you're not ready, we don't. Discretion is the better part of valor.
... Blast. I'm having the anti-air batteries cleared out until I can figure out what the hell is going on.
Damn. What do you recommend we do?
All right, then. Keep it together.
Sure I'm sure. And if I'm sure, the crew are sure.
Bloody hell. Finally.
Feeling better?
I needed that refit. Lucky it wasn't too serious.
Wasn't too serious? One of the AA guns was cracked. We can't be out here with defective equipment.
The Soviet girls seem to make it work.
Don't let them hear you say that.
They won't because I won't. It wasn't defective when we got it.

Fields.MenuText: I didn't realise you were making a habit of those history lectures.
Who do we need to throw overboard?
When will that be?

Fields.DialogueText: That's certainly a factor, but there's more to it than that.
Ideally no one. People make mistakes... and sometimes they're a bloody headache. Well, handache.
Within the week. It's not critical; I've handled worse scrapes than this one.
I don't like this. If there's a saboteur on board...
Sure is useful to be able to detect where there's a mechanical problem.
All the more reason that I incorporate some anatomy lessons into the lectures.
Except when people start falling in love and throwing words around like "future" and "evolution." Or "angel."
You're special, Bulldog, and a symbol besides. People are going to look up to you no matter what.
I won't deny that I enjoy sharing my history with them, and I can't deny the effect on morale. But this is all a bit funny.
I've been getting a lot of questions about those. The crew have been itching for the next one.
You're not saying it was sabotaged?
Not yet, I'm not. I need to ask around at the next class.
Then I've a one-way ticket to Atlantis with their name on it, and I'm not talking about that German cruiser.
Nothing wrong with a little inspiration.
I'd rather they look beside them while they work. Or better yet, at what they're working on. That's where I like to be: in the thick of things. So should we all.
Though if we're being honest, sometimes that worries me more.
*ALARM*
Hardly a note to start a battle on. Apologies, Captain.
Never apologize for yourself, Bulldog. Your performance would be enough even if you had to.
Appreciated, Captain. It's nice to be an equal.
@BATTLE
Don't stop scrubbing, mates! I can still see some grease and oil on my decks! I'm breaking out just thinking about it!
Keeping us ship-shape?
In Bristol fashion, Captain.

Fields.MenuText: Keeping busy while things are quiet?
Good. I like to see the crew working hard.
What happened wasn't everyone's fault.

Fields.DialogueText: No excuse for idle hands at sea. And recent events have convinced me the crew could use the distraction.
I would have ordered it one way or another. A full-body massage, this is. It's good once in a while.
It wasn't, and yet it was.
Collective punishment?
I'm not sure where to begin.
I'm not sure if I should even begin. Seems I'm damned if I do and damned if I don't.
You can't blame yourself for what almost happened to Winthrop. You didn't tell those men to throw her overboard.
I didn't. But I represent my country, my culture. People make connections, especially if they happen to like it.
They weren't even British, were they?
What did I say?
*ALARM*
Oh, sweet bloody hell. Captain, you're right.
Of course not. But fervour is contagious, so I might as well put it to use and buy some time to think.
Something I didn't even want to entertain. It's not Britain they're into. I'll leave it at that.
Right, then, mops down and tempers up! We're switching to the extra strength cleanser!
@BATTLE
Oi! Back away from the guardrail, the both of you! Two metres!
Is that Winthrop?
I'll handle this, Captain.
M-Miss Bulldog!
*ALARM*
Brig. Now. Winthrop, with me. Captain, to the bridge.

Fields.MenuText: I'm surprised they went to the brig when they were told.
Why don't we start from the beginning.
Is Winthrop all right?

Fields.DialogueText: Even loonies can be predictable.
I wish I could pin that down exactly.
More angry than shaken, which I've always considered healthy.
I think it all started around the time of the refit. The gun damage was probably due to some faulty powder bags. Well, someone learned Winthrop had handled them at some point.
Don't even dignify that with speculation.
But why would they have suspected her?
You try answering for cultists. They know I fixed her back. Near as I can tell, it's proximity did the job.
We do love a good betrayal story. Just ask Judas, Lancelot, Iago...
And a few other things besides. I'll be in my quarters, Captain.
Well, they got it. They just had the perspective wrong.
I heard shouting. What's going-
This one was- I mean, it's her fault!
@BATTLE
... Yes, ma'am.
Mental. All of it, mental.
Was she actually-
Ridiculous.
Chin up, lad. Anyone gives you trouble, you come to me. Not a moment's hesitation.
Don't forget our dominoes game. Dismissed.
Anything wrong, Bulldog?
Don't be alarmed, Captain. I just might have to bash some heads in.

Fields.MenuText: I trust you'll take care of it.
You're not going to throw that officer overboard for cowardice?
I'll be the judge of that.

Fields.DialogueText: I do hope you'll intervene if I get carried away. Though some days I don't hope very hard.
Got the wrong Belle there. Anyone who wants to be whipped into shape can be. It just takes the right approach.
If you want to deal with this madness firsthand, feel free. It wouldn't be the same.
He looked haunted. Still worried about his family?
He was last to get to his station from that cleaning spree I set everyone to.
So he didn't win the massage or whatever you had planned for a prize.
First of all, I cut the winner in on my tobacco, so you can shelve your little fantasy.
By whom?
Shelved.
More to the point, he's being watched. Talked about.
Yes, ma'am. It's probably nothing, but... well. By your leave.
He doesn't know their names. But he swears he's seen a couple of ensigns whispering and then shutting up when he looked their way.
You think it might have something to do with your admirers?
I'm hoping he's just paranoid. Paranoia I can deal with.
As opposed to-
Conviction. Wondering if someone's out to get you is one thing. Being certain someone's out to get me... well, you've seen what that can do.
*ALARM*
A common enemy isn't enough?
You want to watch out when people start sniffing round for fifth columns to break. Brings the whole structure down, it does.
@BATTLE
There they are, Bulldog.
Captain?
We're about to engage the Morganas. What's on your mind?
Focusing.
I'll say. That's the biggest cloud of smoke I've ever seen you in.
If I could just have a moment of-
Are you out of your mind? We could be attacked at any minute!
Our officer's in trouble. He's not that far off.

Fields.MenuText: I still can't believe they'd do something like that.
Can we trust the old prisoners?
Were they any trouble?

Fields.DialogueText: I doubt they could believe it either, until fairly recently.
They're gits, but they're not mad, near as I can tell. I'll let you know if that changes.
As before, Captain, they went willingly. They just seemed confused.
I'm just glad I was able to get him off of that bloody lifeboat they'd tied him up on.
What did he say was their reason?
Failure, Captain. He'd failed me by being slow in the execution of his duties.
That's insane. You and I are the judges of that.
... Bulldog?
Bloody hell, no! Captain, we need to come about at once!
Not that... Bulldog, is he off the ship!?
Act now and he won't be. Executive decision, Captain. Radio the rest of the fleet. They need to know what we're doing.
@BATTLE
Looks like the brig just got a little more crowded.
I rotated the old prisoners out. Winthrop's friends are ferrying the potatoes to the galley which our other two culprits will be peeling. Until we can hand them off in port.
Rather inconvenient when your prophet's around to reprimand you, isn't it?
You've got to be kidding.
When I apprehended our attempted murderers, I found they'd come up with a salute for me specifically. I asked - too politely - for them to stop. You tell me.
Bulldog.
Captain.
I didn't expect to see you here in the mess. Class?
In a more participatory style. I reckon I've done enough talking.
What do the crew talk about?
Whatever they please. Home. Family. One hobby or another. I've... ugh. I've asked them to leave us out of it.
Leave who out of it?
Us. The Belles.

Fields.MenuText: But you're the biggest inspiration to win this war.
Your voice must be thanking you.
Why would you do that?

Fields.DialogueText: That's the problem, isn't it? There is such a thing as too much inspiration.
It's been a fair stretch since I could just sit and smoke. I might never go back.
Because I'd sooner be scrapped than give them any more bloody ideas.
Bulldog, what happened wasn't your fault. You can't answer for everyone who does wrong in your name.
I can bloody well cut out the middleman.
I hate to break it to you, but we're stuck with you.
Me and whichever other nutter decides I need protecting, or veneration, or whatever else.
So your solution is what? Fade into the background?
What was the name of the officer I rescued?
Yet he does his job like the rest of us. My job just happens to be different. Not bigger, not better. Different. And that's all there is to it.
@BATTLE
... I don't rightly recall.
Now, off we trot. Unless I miss my guess, we're not alone in these waters.
I'm sure HQ told us as soon as they knew, Bulldog.
A lesser Belle would needle them until they developed precognition.
Tempting, isn't it?
Maybe we'll get an oracle out of the Greek navy. I could use a modern-day Cassandra.
Which would put us right where we are anyway. All this fiddling about in the Atlantic... None of it kept the Morganas from plotting a strike on the Isles.

Fields.MenuText: We'll get there, Bulldog.
We're going to bury them so far underwater they won't know which way is up.
It's not your fault.

Fields.DialogueText: I'll keep telling myself that. The Channel's a right pig's ear.
Glad you've been keeping up.
Any more dithering and it'll become my fault.
I may be splitting my focus over these next few days. Just concentrating on my engines. I'm pushing us as hard as I can.
I understand.
For someone who doesn't like the spotlight, you sure do some great things with it.
Anyone could. Sometimes I wish someone else would.
Can you imagine fighting this war without Belles?
Against the Morganas? You'd lose the coasts inside of a year.
Even if it gets people hurt.
Especially if it gets people hurt.
We've never had symbols that could speak for themselves.
*ALARM*
You'll learn to live with the Morganas with us around, Captain. I suppose I just wish more people could learn to live with us. At least without being so... so...
Wasn't she cursed to have nobody listen to her predictions?
No reason to seize the spotlight until it's fixed upon me.
But you know how to fight humans. You pick causes and symbols and rally around them, and they mean whatever you need them to mean.
Interruptive?
Works for my purposes.
@BATTLE
HQ reported that the Morganas were spotted massing near Scarborough and heading south.
Of course they did. London's always been the target.
They've been shelling some of the smaller towns along their way south, but so far the damage isn't too bad.
Be a damn nightmare if they get up the Thames.

Fields.MenuText: Don't let it happen.
Don't blame yourself.
Don't doubt London.

Fields.DialogueText: It's not a pattern unless it happens thrice.
We've done our best at every turn. Nothing for it but to keep on.
I don't doubt their hearts, but they haven't much of a home guard.
I hope I haven't been bringing the mood down, Captain.
You'd know better than I would.
I've been scarce lately.
You've been working yourself overtime to get us home.
We'd still be in the middle of the open ocean without the crew. If I've failed to teach them anything else, I hope they realise at least that.
... Come, cheer up, my lads, 'tis to glory we steer, to add something new to this wonderful year...
Failed? What are you-
... Bulldog... I hate to interrupt, but-
No, Captain, I hear it too. Is that...
Sabotage, Captain. Lollygagging. We've thrown four crew in the brig for appointing themselves judge and jury of made-up sins.
Against whom? Me? I'm a destroyer. I can't help what I'm called or where I'm from. All I can do is protect the place that made me; the kingdom the Morganas are trying to drown.
I didn't need defending. My home did. And what's everyone going to remember? London's finest hour, or mine? And how are they going to remember it? Who's in trouble for forgetting?
The crew, they're... singing?
Heart of Oak...
Your song?
Not my song, Captain. Britain's.
We're almost there. Whether we're ready or not-
I reckon we might be.
@BATTLE
Steady as she goes, Bulldog.
Steady as I go.
... Yes. That.
You can laugh if you want, Captain. I certainly am.
@BATTLE
Listening to the crew again?
A bit. I need to know that they're ready for whatever we might see when we get back into the channel proper.
Well, don't try it incognito. You're not exactly King Henry the Fifth.
I'll take that under advisement. They look up to you, you know.
Yes, I believe we've discussed this.

Fields.MenuText: You heard them during the approach to London. It sounds like they got your message.

Fields.DialogueText: I should hope so. I've certainly talked enough about it.
I was born into a role, Captain, and I like to think I've done the best I can with it.
I love my country. That's what keeps me going. All the crew have something like that. It's what makes us a team. If we can share all those things... that's enough for me.

Fields.MenuText: You can't judge your fan club by its zealots.

Fields.DialogueText: I can certainly judge the zealots. Thankfully my fan club approve.

Fields.MenuText: It's not just you. It's what you represent.

Fields.DialogueText: More often than not, that's the case. I'm starting to see that.
You earned it. We've kept them out of the Thames. Just one more sweep and we can celebrate.
The worst of it's over. It's just us and them now.
Learning a lot today.
Yeah?
Both the crew and me. I finally started talking again.

Fields.MenuText: They must have missed that.
That explains the singing.

Fields.DialogueText: I admit I tell a halfway decent story.
I can't help it if they love my voice.
Do you know what's different about my stories, Captain?
I imagine you've got more of them.
A thousand years more, Captain. But I wasn't there for any of it. The glory and the pain... none of it's mine. I'm an ambassador for those who earned it.
But just one part. So when I befriend the crew and forge them into a fighting force... I want them to be proud of their role in it. To give them something not to aspire to... but to surpass.
Hence your interest in their life stories.
They're all heroes in their own. I wouldn't have them aboard if they weren't.
*ALARM*
We're keeping the kill tally, though.
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: What about?

Fields.DialogueText: Trafalgar. Someone asked me about it and that took up the better part of a half hour. I try not to talk that much, but I can get going.
Of course. And the song. 'Tis to glory we steer, after all.
You're part of something bigger.
Mind if I join you up here?
Of course not, Skipper, if you don't mind my pipe.
So...
The rest of the crew are celebrating.
A right kicker, too. I can hear them partying on the pier from up here.
I'd say they all earned it, after that last battle.
No disagreements there.
And yet, here you are, alone.
Maybe they earned a break from me, too.
And from me. We don't have to spoil their fun.

Fields.MenuText: This war isn't over yet, Bulldog. They still need us.

Fields.DialogueText: We Belles wouldn't be here if you didn't.
And England will always need a fast ship with a Heart of Oak.
Here we are.
It kept me going, having somebody leading the way that I could trust.
I trusted the crew, too. We wouldn't be here if not for them.
They had you to look up to. Even if you had to make them keep their eyes forward.

Fields.MenuText: You were a hero out there.
You've earned a break.

Fields.DialogueText: Sitting and smoking, Captain. The war's back on tomorrow.
Can't stripe my hull with a trophy. I'll be glad to be back out there.
They're on the run, Bulldog! Keep it coming!
Tell the crew to keep singing, Captain. I'm on percussion!
@BATTLE
That's about where my eyes are right now.
Inland?
It's interesting, Captain. The way you make your heroes. Your saints. You look through history and find great people to tell the stories you're looking for.
That's what makes you Belles different. When we talk to our history, you talk back.
Maybe we're not so different after all. I can't go ashore any more than you can go back in time.
So where does that leave us?
Making it safe to try.
I'll let you know when I've found a way.
There's always tomorrow, Captain. We'll make sure of it.
